summary: crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) is a member of the genus Nairovirus in the family Bunyaviridae. CCHFV is one of the most widely spread tick-borne viral infection of humans. CCHFV is one of the most widely spread tick-borne virus of humans. NSs have been shown to induce caspase activation and apoptosis. NSs proteins in the Bunyaviridae family exhibit sequence similarity with a known proapoptotic protein, reaper, from Drosophila (7). CCHFV induces caspase-3-dependent apoptosis (22) and modulates both intrinsic as well as extrinsic pathways of apoptosis in hepatocyte cells. CCHFV suppresses caspase activation at early stages of the infection and induces host cellular pro-apoptotic molecules at late stages post-infection. CCHFV NSs protein induces caspase-3/7 activation and PARP cleavage. this is the first time that NSs protein has been shown to induce apoptosis. NSs protein of the same genus can delay cell death by counteracting IRF-3-mediated apoptosis. caspase-dependent NSs-induced apoptosis involves both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways. CCHFV NSs has been predicted to possess a transmembrane helix domain (118–135 amino acids) that contains the leu-127 and leu-135 residues important for CCHFV NSs-induced apoptosis. NSs of hepatitis C virus has been reported to associate with the mitochondria of infected cells, contributing to an increase in reactive oxygen species, leading to apoptosis (43). on the other hand, NSm of the same virus integrates into the mitochondrial outer membrane and exerts an antiapoptotic function. CCHFV NSs co-localizes with mtTFA. NS4A of the hepatitis C virus activates caspase-8 and -9. p7 protein of the hepatitis C virus activates caspase-8 and -9 to induce apoptosis. ectopic expression of NSs wild-type and mutant proteins induces apoptosis.
